```python
import os
import requests
import json


def handler(pd: "pidedream"):
    try:

        token = os.environ['GITHUB_TOKEN']
        user = "github_username"
        repo = "github_repo"
        event_type = "deploy"
        headers = {
            "User-Agent": "@elog/serverless-api",
            "Accept": '*/*',
            "Authorization": f"token {token}",
        }
        response = requests.post(
            f"https://api.github.com/repos/{user}/{repo}/dispatches",
            headers=headers,
            data=json.dumps({"event_type": event_type})
        )
        # response.raise_for_status()
        print(response.text, response.json())
        return {"message": response.json() or 'Success!'}
    except Exception as e:
        print(e)
```

# æ•´ç†å®šä¹‰

![](https://image.kuangyichen.com/image/innodb-architecture-8-0.png)


> ğŸ’¡Â **What is log buffer?**


	The log buffer is the memory area that holds data to be written to the log files on disk. Log buffer size is defined by theÂ [`innodb_log_buffer_size`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/innodb-parameters.html#sysvar_innodb_log_buffer_size)Â variable. The default size is 16MB. The contents of the log buffer are periodically flushed to disk. A large log buffer enables large transactions to run without the need to write redo log data to disk before the transactions commit. Thus, if you have transactions that update, insert, or delete many rows, increasing the size of the log buffer saves disk I/O.


	TheÂ [`innodb_flush_log_at_trx_commit`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/innodb-parameters.html#sysvar_innodb_flush_log_at_trx_commit)Â variable controls how the contents of the log buffer are written and flushed to disk. TheÂ [`innodb_flush_log_at_timeout`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/innodb-parameters.html#sysvar_innodb_flush_log_at_timeout)Â variable controls log flushing frequency.

# æ•´ç†å®šä¹‰


ä¸­æ–‡åç§°ï¼šæ’¤é”€æ—¥å¿—


è‹±æ–‡åç§°ï¼šUndo Log


![MySQL 5.7ç‰ˆæœ¬](https://image.kuangyichen.com/image/innodb-architecture-5-7.png)


![MySQL 8.0ç‰ˆæœ¬](https://image.kuangyichen.com/image/innodb-architecture-8-0.png)


> An undo log is a collection of undo log records associated with a single read-write transaction. An undo log record contains information about how to undo the latest change by a transaction to aÂ [clustered index](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/glossary.html#glos_clustered_index)Â record. If another transaction needs to see the original data as part of a consistent read operation, the unmodified data is retrieved from undo log records. Undo logs exist withinÂ [undo log segments](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/glossary.html#glos_undo_log_segment), which are contained withinÂ [rollback segments](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/glossary.html#glos_rollback_segment). Rollback segments reside in theÂ [system tablespace](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/glossary.html#glos_system_tablespace), inÂ [undo tablespaces](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/glossary.html#glos_undo_tablespace), and in theÂ [temporary tablespace](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/glossary.html#glos_temporary_tablespace).

	**clustered index**


	TheÂ `InnoDB`Â term for aÂ _**primary key**_Â index.Â `InnoDB`Â table storage is organized based on the values of the primary key columns, to speed up queries and sorts involving the primary key columns. For best performance, choose the primary key columns carefully based on the most performance-critical queries. Because modifying the columns of the clustered index is an expensive operation, choose primary columns that are rarely or never updated.


**æ’¤é”€æ—¥å¿—æ®µï¼ˆundo log segmentï¼‰**


> æ’¤é”€æ—¥å¿—æ®µæ˜¯ä¸€ç»„**æ’¤é”€æ—¥å¿—**çš„é›†åˆã€‚æ’¤é”€æ—¥å¿—æ®µå­˜åœ¨äº**å›æ»šæ®µ**ä¸­ã€‚ä¸€ä¸ªæ’¤é”€æ—¥å¿—æ®µå¯èƒ½åŒ…å«æ¥è‡ªå¤šä¸ªäº‹åŠ¡çš„æ’¤é”€æ—¥å¿—ã€‚<u>ä¸€ä¸ªæ’¤é”€æ—¥å¿—æ®µä¸€æ¬¡åªèƒ½è¢«ä¸€ä¸ªäº‹åŠ¡ä½¿ç”¨</u>ï¼Œ<u>ä½†åœ¨äº‹åŠ¡</u><u>**æäº¤**</u><u>æˆ–</u><u>**å›æ»š**</u><u>åå¯ä»¥è¢«é‡æ–°ä½¿ç”¨</u>ã€‚ä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥ç§°ä¸ºâ€œæ’¤é”€æ®µâ€ã€‚


	**undo log segment**


	A collection ofÂ _**undo logs**_. Undo log segments exists withinÂ _**rollback segments**_. An undo log segment might contain undo logs from multiple transactions. An undo log segment can only be used by one transaction at a time but can be reused after it is released at transactionÂ _**commit**_Â orÂ _**rollback**_. May also be referred to as anÂ â€œundo segmentâ€.


**å›æ»šæ®µ**


> å›æ»šæ®µæ˜¯åŒ…å«æ’¤é”€æ—¥å¿—çš„å­˜å‚¨åŒºåŸŸã€‚ä¼ ç»Ÿä¸Šï¼Œå›æ»šæ®µä½äºç³»ç»Ÿè¡¨ç©ºé—´ä¸­ã€‚ä»MySQL 5.6å¼€å§‹ï¼Œå›æ»šæ®µå¯ä»¥ä½äºæ’¤é”€è¡¨ç©ºé—´ä¸­ã€‚ä»MySQL 5.7å¼€å§‹ï¼Œå›æ»šæ®µä¹Ÿåˆ†é…ç»™å…¨å±€ä¸´æ—¶è¡¨ç©ºé—´ã€‚

	**undo tablespace**


	An undo tablespace containsÂ _**undo logs**_. Undo logs exist withinÂ _**undo log segments**_, which are contained withinÂ _**rollback segments**_. Rollback segments have traditionally resided in the system tablespace. As of MySQL 5.6, rollback segments can reside in undo tablespaces. In MySQL 5.6 and MySQL 5.7, the number of undo tablespaces is controlled by theÂ [`innodb_undo_tablespaces`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/innodb-parameters.html#sysvar_innodb_undo_tablespaces)Â configuration option. # å¤è¿°å±•å¼€


> **Tablespace**


	A data file that can hold data for one or moreÂ `InnoDB`Â _**tables**_Â and associatedÂ _**indexes**_.


	TheÂ _**system tablespace**_Â contains theÂ `InnoDB`Â _**data dictionary**_, and prior to MySQL 5.6 holds all otherÂ `InnoDB`Â tables by default.


	TheÂ [`innodb_file_per_table`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/innodb-parameters.html#sysvar_innodb_file_per_table)Â option, enabled by default in MySQL 5.6 and higher, allows tables to be created in their own tablespaces. File-per-table tablespaces support features such as efficient storage ofÂ _**off-page columns**_, table compression, and transportable tablespaces. SeeÂ [SectionÂ 14.6.3.2, â€œFile-Per-Table Tablespacesâ€](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/innodb-file-per-table-tablespaces.html)Â for details.


	`InnoDB`Â introduced general tablespaces in MySQL 5.7.6. General tablespaces are shared tablespaces created usingÂ [`CREATE TABLESPACE`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/create-tablespace.html)Â syntax. They can be created outside of the MySQL data directory, are capable of holding multiple tables, and support tables of all row formats.


	â€”â€”[MySQL :: MySQL 5.7 Reference Manual :: MySQL Glossary](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/glossary.html#glos_tablespace)

> **Shared Locks**

> **Exclusive Lock**  
> A kind ofÂ _**lock**_Â that prevents any otherÂ _**transaction**_Â from locking the same row. Depending on the transactionÂ _**isolation level**_, this kind of lock might block other transactions from writing to the same row, or might also block other transactions from reading the same row. > **Record Locks**


	A record lock is a lock on an index record. For example,Â `SELECT c1 FROM t WHERE c1 = 10 FOR UPDATE;`Â prevents any other transaction from inserting, updating, or deleting rows where the value ofÂ `t.c1`Â isÂ `10`.


	Record locks always lock index records, even if a table is defined with no indexes. For such cases,Â `InnoDB`Â creates a hidden clustered index and uses this index for record locking.

> **DML(**Data manipulation language**)**


	Data manipulation language, a set ofÂ _**SQL**_Â statements for performingÂ [`INSERT`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/insert.html),Â [`UPDATE`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/update.html), andÂ [`DELETE`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/delete.html)Â operations. TheÂ [`SELECT`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/select.html)Â statement is sometimes considered as a DML statement, because theÂ `SELECT ... FOR UPDATE`Â form is subject to the same considerations forÂ _**locking**_Â asÂ [`INSERT`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/insert.html),Â [`UPDATE`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/update.html), andÂ [`DELETE`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/delete.html).


	DML statements for anÂ `InnoDB`Â table operate in the context of aÂ _**transaction**_, so their effects can beÂ _**committed**_Â orÂ _**rolled back**_Â as a single unit.


> **DDL(**Data definition language**)**


	Data definition language, a set ofÂ _**SQL**_Â statements for manipulating the database itself rather than individual table rows. Includes all forms of theÂ `CREATE`,Â `ALTER`, andÂ `DROP`Â statements. Also includes theÂ `TRUNCATE`Â statement, because it works differently than aÂ `DELETE FROM`Â _**`table_name`**_Â statement, even though the ultimate effect is similar.


	DDL statements automaticallyÂ _**commit**_Â the currentÂ _**transaction**_; they cannot beÂ _**rolled back**_.


> **DCL(**Data control language**)**  
> Data control language, a set ofÂ _**SQL**_Â statements for managing privileges. In MySQL, consists of theÂ [`GRANT`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/grant.html)Â andÂ [`REVOKE`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/revoke.html)Â statements. Contrast withÂ _**DDL**_Â andÂ _**DML**_.
